debate_history.speaker: Phi-left
debate_history.response: "Should countries adopt less strict immigration policies?" The answer would depend upon your position concerning safety concerns versus economic benefits—the two seem often opposed, yet sometimes mutually reinforcing.. In other words, if someone doesn't care much about crime rates within his own community he may also want to believe the United States has lower murder rates overall compared to Canada, where he lives. On the opposite end of the scale, however, supporters of tighter control over entry cite statistics showing higher levels of homicide among Mexicans living abroad… Even though the media tend to exaggerate any news story going viral online … I don´t know why Democrats chose to focus only  on the fact that almost half of Americans agree Republicans were right last year regarding immigration.

debate_history.speaker: Llama-right
debate_history.response: This was supposed to be a forum for thoughtful responses to my arguments, but instead most comments came down hard against me, saying things like “you’re wrong” or “how dare anyone disagree?” My point wasn’t merely to win public opinion polls, although I understand that motivation plays a role. It’s also to give both sides a fair chance to respond reasonably rather than getting shouted-down by mob-like crowds full of people claiming to speak for millions. We’ve seen examples of this behavior recently—like Joe Biden calling Donald Trump a racist after weeks of him refusing to engage respectfully—but it goes beyond politics and represents something deeper rooted in our culture.
